subject: Re: [junit] How to test private methods in a class.
msgSnippet: ... Start with a roadmap, rather than just Javadoc. What you describe is a limitation of the Javadoc concept, rather than a limitation of any particular API
messageBody:
Elliotte Harold wrote:
> Ilja Preuss wrote:
>
> > I don't think that's true. I don't see how having an additional
> > org.something.util.CalendarParser class could make any library harder to
> > understand and use. Hell, that class could even be extracted to a
> different
> > binary, so that an outside developer wouldn't see it at all.
>
> Have you really never tried to work your way through a mess of JavaDoc
> with no easy way to figure out what classes you needed and what you
> could ignore? Has it been that long since you learned a new API?
> Featuritis isn't just a problem for applications. It applies to
> libraries too. Smaller is better. Too large an API becomes a problem.

Start with a roadmap, rather than just Javadoc. What you describe is a
limitation of the Javadoc concept, rather than a limitation of any
particular API design. Javadoc describes classes and methods, but
doesn't necessarily help you know where to start.

To use JUnit as the example, there are a number of good tutorials. Many
freely available packages now use a familiar pattern on their sites:

* One minute tutorial
* Two minute tutorial
* Ten minute tutorial
* Javadoc/reference guide

I think this is great. The next API I publish should include this.

> Probably half of what's there could be
> non-public, and users would be the better off for it if it were. What
> benefit is served by making junit.samples or TestResult$1 public?

I wish the code to extract test methods were public and non-static! I've
wanted to reuse or override that a number of times. If, instead, it were
a pluggable TestNamingStrategy, I wouldn't have that problem, but that
would mean a collaborator behind an interface....

For every example you give, I can find another. That game's boring. :)
